Table 3 Catalyst Fe 2p3/2 a Fe 2p1/2 b Fe5C2/ Fe3O4 c 706.9 710.9 719.2 724.3 FM 28 535 40 280 0.08 CP 34 400 45 180 0.14 SR 25 180 18 90 0.16 a,b:represent the area of Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 from XPS peak fitting. c:the whole area ratio of Fe5C2 and Fe3O4. γ-Fe2O3 as the precursor of iron based catalyst prepared by solid-state reaction at room temperature for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins Wenfeng Han ⁎ Lingyu Wang Zhi Li Haodong Tang Ying Li Chao Huo Guojun Lan Xiazhen Yang Huazhang Liu ⁎ Institute of Industrial Catalysis, Zhejiang University of Technology, 18 Chaowang Road, Hangzhou 310032, Zhejiang, PR China Institute of Industrial Catalysis Zhejiang University of Technology 18 Chaowang Road Hangzhou Zhejiang 310032 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Iron catalyst was fabricated via simple solid-state reaction of metal nitrates mixture (Fe, K, Al, Ca, Mg, Sm) with oxalic acid dihydrate at room temperature. Iron catalysts prepared by conventional methods, such as co-precipitation and fusing, are also included as comparison. The performances of catalysts were evaluated by the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) in a fixed bed reactor. The results indicate that uniform nanoparticles were obtained with surface area as high as 38.7 m2/g prepared by solid-state reaction. Following calcination at 500 °C, γ-Fe2O3 were obtained as the catalyst precursor. By contrast, α-Fe2O3 was the main precursor derived from co-precipitation. In addition, γ-Fe2O3 prepared by solid-state reaction facilitates the formation of active phase, Fe5C2 with the exposure of (021) facet. High Miller index surface (021) facilitates the adsorption and the dissociation of CO, which contributes the high activity and high selectivity to light olefins. Consequently, compared with conventional catalysts, solid-state reaction derived catalysts exhibit much higher FTO reaction activity and selectivity to lower olefins. The FTY value of 5.62 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1 was obtained which is almost two times higher than that of catalyst prepared by co-precipitation (3.19 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1) or 3 times higher than that of catalyst prepared by fusing method (1.98 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1). The selectivity to light olefins of around 40% is obtained which is significantly higher than that of the reference catalysts (25% and 33% respectively). The present study provides a promising pathway to prepare iron based catalysts at room temperature. Keywords Iron catalyst Solid-state reaction FTO γ-Fe2O3 Lower olefin Fe5C2 1 Introduction Lower olefins, including ethylene, propylene and butylene, are the key feedstock for the manufacture of plastics, drugs, cosmetics and detergents [1]. Generally, lower olefins are produced by the thermal or catalytic cracking of naphtha or oil [2,3]. Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and propane were also suggested for the synthesis of ethylene, propylene [4,5]. However, the shortage of oil and natural gas resource and environmental issues pose significant challenges for the development and commercial application of these traditional routes. Consequently, alternative routes, especially Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) has been considered as a promising and attractive route for the direct and single-step conversion of syngas to lower olefins [6,7]. Syngas can be derived from biomass, coal and natural gas with relatively low cost [8–10]. It is well accepted that iron based catalysts are the major catalysts for FTO process due to the high selectivity toward lower olefins, lower cost, as well as the high water-gas-shift activity which enables the catalysts to adjust H2/CO ratio and improve product distribution during FTO process [11,12]. However, the products of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) are confined by the rule of Anderson-Shultz-Flory (ASF) distribution [13]. The ASF model well predicts the maximum selectivity to C2-C4 hydrocarbons, including olefins and alkanes, being lower than 58% [14]. Catalyst plays a major role in the selectivity for FTS process. Therefore, the research and development of proper catalysts with high activity and selectivity to light olefins in FTO reaction is the key and has attracted increasing attention. Recently, Wei et al [15] prepared graphene oxide supported iron catalysts via hydrothermal method with ferrous acetate (Fe(C2H3O2)2), ferric oxalate (Fe2(C2O4)3) and ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3) as the precursors, respectively. Fe2(C2O4)3 was found to be proper precursor with high FTS activity and C5+ selectivity, due to the reducibility and carbonization. Hong et al [16] fabricated carbon encapsulated Fe5C2 nanoparticles via thermal treatment under CO flow with uniform iron oxalate dihydrate micro-cubes as the precursor. Fe5C2@C catalyst exhibited high activity (with CO conversion of 96%, FTY of 1.5 × 10 ̶ 4 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1) and stability (90 h). In addition, the intermediates, iron oxides play important roles in the performance of catalysts [17]. It was confirmed that α-Fe2O3 favors the formation of light olefins, and while γ-Fe2O3 facilitates the production of long chain hydrocarbons. The difference was attributed to structure evolution during the activation and reaction process. For α-Fe2O3, it follows α-Fe2O3 → α-Fe3O4 → α-Fe → χ-Fe5C2. By contrast, γ-Fe2O3 undergoes the procedure of γ-Fe2O3 → γ-Fe3O4 → γ-Fe → θ-Fe3C [17]. Unfortunately, very few reports were focused on the investigation of γ-Fe2O3 for FTO. Generally, α-Fe2O3 was obtained by traditional precipitation method [18,19]. Clearly, ferric oxalate is potential precursor with high activity and stability for FTO. Therefore, we attempted to synthesize γ-Fe2O3 with ferric oxalate as the precursor. It is well accepted that the primary goals of FTO are to maximize light olefins selectivity, to reduce methane and C5+ selectivity, and to avoid the formation of excess CO2. In addition to the preparation method, electronic or structural promoters also play major roles in product distribution. Among various promoters, potassium, alumina, calcium, magnesium and samarium were considered as effective electronic or structural promoters. Among the promoters, potassium promotes CO adsorption and dissociation. It increases the selectivity to lower olefins and long chain hydrocarbon, inhibiting the formation of methane [20–23]. As a structural promoter, alumina improves the distribution of copper and potassium, resulting in high activity during FTS [24]. In addition, the strong interaction between alumina and K also contributes to the catalytic reaction [25]. Alkaline-earth metals (magnesium, calcium) are considered as the typical electronic promoters, which favor the formation of olefins and heavy hydrocarbons rather than methane [26]. Especially, samarium, a rare promoter in FTS process, was confirmed to improve the specific surface area of Fe2O3 [27]. Hence, in the present work, we report the K/Al/Ca/Mg/Sm promoted γ-Fe2O3 catalysts with ferric oxalate as the precursor. The catalysts were prepared via simple solid-state reaction at room temperature. Solid-state reaction is considered as one of efficient ways for the preparation of nanomaterials. It involves the phase rebuilding, phase transformation and crystal detachment. Clearly, the mass transfer plays an important role in the solid-state reaction. Melting is one of the major routes for the mass transfer during solid state reaction. As the reactants possess low Taman temperatures, they undergo phase transformation or water detachment at temperatures derived from grinding. As comparison, catalysts prepared by co-precipitation and melting methods were also included. Prepared via simple solid-state reaction, catalyst with high surface area and uniform small particles, showed much higher catalytic activity and selectivity to lower olefins during FTO than traditional precipitated and fused catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Iron based catalysts were prepared by solid-state reaction at room temperature, co-precipitation and fusing methods respectively. They were denoted as SR for solid-state reaction, CP for co-precipitation and FM for fusing method, respectively. SR catalyst was obtained via solid-state reaction at room temperature. According to the molar ratio of Fe/K/Al/Ca/Mg/Sm = 1/0.0116/0.0227/0.0136/0.0094/0.0067, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Aladdin, AR) and other promoters (also with nitrates as the precursors) were added in an agate mortar (Beijing Honghu, 100 mm), then manually ground for 5 min in order to mix promoters and iron precursor more uniformly. Then, 3.97 g oxalic acid dihydrate (Yonghua Chemical Technology of China, AR) was added and milled constantly. The color was changed from deep yellow to brilliant yellow in 20 min (Fig. S1). Following further milling for 30 min, no color change was observed. During the milling, large amounts of pungent gases were emitted (NOx). Finally, the homogeneous mixture paste was transferred into a beaker, and then dried at 110 °C overnight. Following calcination at 500 °C for 2 h in air, SR catalyst was obtained. CP catalyst was prepared by traditional co-precipitation method [28]. Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Aladdin, AR) and promoter precursors, including Al(NO3)3·9H2O (Aladdin, AR), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (Aladdin, AR), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR) and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O (Aladdin, AR) with Fe/Al/Ca/Mg/Sm molar ratio of 1/0.0227/0.0136/0.0094/0.0067 were dissolved in 20 mL distillated water at 50 °C. 0.003 mol/mL (NH4)2CO3 (Aladdin, AR) solution was adopted as the precipitant. With vigorous stirring, (NH4)2CO3 solution was dropwise added to the precursor solution maintaining the pH at 7.0. The precipitate was aged for 1 h at room temperature and washed with deionized water for three times. Subsequently, the precipitate was dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in air. Finally, 0.04 g KNO3 was impregnated followed by the same drying and calcination procedure again. FM was prepared using melting method [29]. Magnetite and ferrous powder were mixed with promoter precursors (Al2O3, KNO3, CaO, MgO and Sm2O3, Aladdin, AR). The composition is exactly the same as M2 and PM2. Then the mixture was melted at 1500–1700 °C. The molten material was quenched in water. Finally, all catalysts were crushed and sieved to 20–40 mesh for catalytic performance test. Clearly, this method is totally different from that of SR catalyst via solid-state reaction. Although melting process may also be involved, the solid-state reaction takes place at room temperatures. Consequently, it facilitates the formation of nanoparticles. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on TF20 (Joel 2100 F) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The textural properties of the catalysts were determined by N2 physisorption at −196 °C with an Autosorb-IQ3 instrument. Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 90 °C for 0.5 h and 300 °C for 6 h. The data were collected at a relative pressure (P/P0) ranging from 0.1 to 1.0. The morphology of the catalysts was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a Hitachi S-4700 (Ⅱ) electron microscope (Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The crystal structures of the catalysts were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) over a PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.154056 nm, 2θ = 10° ˜ 80°). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of samples (weight of about 10 mg catalyst) were obtained on a P X 200 catalyst characterization instrument. H2/Ar mixture (5% H2-95% Ar) or CO/Ar mixture (10% CO-90% Ar) was used as the reducing gas and heated at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 to 850 °C with the flow rate of 30 mL/min (H2-TPR for TCD detector, CO-TPR for mass spectrometer). CO2-TPD profiles of samples with 100 mg were performed on a P X 200 catalyst characterization instrument using Ar as the carrier gas. The samples were reduced at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 to 500 °C with the H2 flow rate of 30 mL/min for 2 h. CO2 adsorption on the catalyst was performed at 100 °C for 1.5 h and the samples were purged with Ar for 0.5 h to remove physically adsorbed species, respectively. When the temperature was increased to 850 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min under Ar flow, and the effluent gases were recorded by a mass spectrometer (m/e = 2 for H2, 28 for CO and 44 for CO2). For X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments, a spectrometer from Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD photoelectron spectroscopy with a monochromatized microfocused Al X-ray source was employed. Charging of samples was corrected by setting the binding energy of adventitious carbon (C 1 s) at 284.6 eV. Prior to the measurements, the powder sample, pressed into self-supporting disks, was loaded into a sub-chamber and then evacuated at 25 °C for 4 h. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) was carried out on an ARL ADVANT’X IntelliPowerTM 4200 instrument to analyze the composition of fresh catalysts. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The FTO performance of catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reactor (id = 11 mm). Firstly, 0.5 mL of catalyst with 7.5 mL of quartz beads were mixed uniformly and was loaded to the isothermal region of the reactor. Before the activity test, the catalysts were reduced successively in H2 atmosphere at 400 °C, 425 °C, 450 °C, 475 °C and 500 °C for 1 h, 1 h, 6 h, 1 h, and 1 h respectively with the pressure of 1.0 MPa and space velocity of 10,000 h ̶ 1. Catalytic performance tests were carried at 320 °C, pressure of 1.0 MPa, GHSV of 11,400 h ̶ 1 and H2/CO of 1.6. Tail gas from reactor were analyzed by GC-2014 (Shimadzu, Japan). C1-C4 hydrocarbons were analyzed using an Al2O3 capillary column with a flame ionization detector (FID). CO, CO2, CH4 were analyzed by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a Porapak Q- and a TDX-01 packed column. The liquid and wax products were collected by a cold trap (0 °C) and a hot trap (130 °C), respectively. The CO conversion was calculated by the following formula: X C O = F i n × Y C O ( i n ) - F o u t × Y C O ( o u t ) F i n × Y C O ( i n ) × 100 % Where Fin and YCO,(in) are the volumetric rate and CO molar fraction of inlet flow, respectively. By contrast, Fout and YCO,(out) are the volumetric rate and CO molar fraction of outlet flow. The selectivity to CO2 was calculated according to: S C O 2 = F o u t × Y C O 2 , ( o u t ) F i n × Y C O ( i n ) × X C O × 100 % where YCO2 denotes CO2 molar fraction of outlet flow. The selectivity to hydrocarbons based on CO2-free was obtained according to: S C i = F o u t × Y C i , o u t × i F i n × Y C O , i n - F o u t × Y C O , o u t - F o u t × Y C O 2 , o u t × 100 % Selectivity to light olefins: S C 2 - 4 = = S C 2 = + S C 3 = + S C 4 = Selectivity to C5+: S C 5 + = 100 - S C O 2 - S C 1 - C 4 Where i is the carbon atom number in the corresponding C i hydrocarbon from 1 to 4. YCi,out represents molar fraction of the hydrocarbon with carbon number i at the outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties N2 physisorption was adopted to illustrate the textural properties of fresh catalysts. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of fresh catalysts were listed in Table 1 . Clearly, the SR catalyst derived from solid-state reaction possesses the highest specific surface area (39 m2 g ̶ 1) and pore volume (0.29 mL g ̶ 1), respectively, which are significantly higher than that of CP catalyst and FM catalyst. Similar results with the data of preparation iron (CP) were also reported by other research works [12,21]. As indicated in Fig. 1 (a), SR and CP samples present type IV adsorption-desorption isotherm with an evident H3-Type hysteresis loop, implying that the catalysts were mesoporous materials. Type H3 loops suggests an irregular pore structure [30]. Pore size distributions were plotted in Fig. 1(b). SR catalyst displays a wide range of pore size distribution. 3.2 Morphology and phase structure The SEM images of all the fresh and reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . For fresh catalysts, preparation method affects the morphology, texture, particle size and the degree of particles agglomeration significantly. Clearly, SR catalyst prepared by solid-state reaction method (Fig. 2b) is composed by a large number of small and homogeneous particles with loose structure. Precipitated iron catalyst (CP) also exhibits small particles with uniformly and tightly stacked structure (Fig. 2a). However, the SEM image of fused catalyst (Fig. 2c) indicates a solid and smooth surface with refractory oxides aggregated on the surface of catalyst. Hence, high surface and pore volume of SR catalyst is attributed to the loose structure, which is consistent with BET results. Following reduction, uniform and fine nanoparticles were derived for SR catalyst with the size of about 50 nm (Fig. 2e). Relatively larger particles were observed for CP catalyst with average particle size of around 70 nm (Fig. 2d). By contrast, after reduced in H2, FM catalyst displays a porous sponge-like structure with coarse surface, indicating the channel development as bulk oxygen atoms were eliminated during reduction [30]. Clearly, particles are aggregated and intensively packed in reduced FM catalyst (Fig. 2f). XRF (X Ray Fluorescence) technique was adopted for the determination of elemental composition of fresh catalysts, and the data are listed in Table S1. The compositions are very close to that of doping amounts during the preparation of catalysts. XRD patterns of fresh catalysts prepared by co-precipitation, melting method, solid-state reaction are displayed in Fig. 3 . The phase structure identified in precipitated iron catalyst (CP) is α-Fe2O3 (JCPDC 33-0664) and no other impurities are detected. However, the phase structure of SR catalyst prepared by solid-state reaction agrees well with γ-Fe2O3 (JCPDC 39–1346). For fused iron catalyst (FM), clear phase structure of Fe3O4 (JCPDC 77–1545) and FeO (JCPDC 75–1550) are suggested. For all the three catalysts, no XRD diffraction peaks of promoters are detected, indicating the high dispersion of promoters in these catalysts. Clearly, following different preparation routes, totally different phase structures of iron oxides are obtained. It was reported that the phase structure of iron oxides plays a major role in CO2 hydrogenation [17]. Consequently, we suggest that these catalysts with different iron oxide structures also differs in the activity and product distribution for FTO reactions. In addition, the crystallite sizes of fresh catalysts were calculated using the FWHM values of the strongest diffraction peak (2θ = 33.15 for CP, 2θ = 35.63 for SR, 2θ = 41.9 for FM) by Scherrer formula. The results are listed in Table S2. The crystal size of SR is 24.9 nm, similar to the catalyst of CP (25.4 nm). However, the crystallite size of FeO particles for FM catalyst is 43.6 nm which agree well with the results of particle size observed by SEM. 3.3 FTO performance As argued previously, SR catalyst derived with γ-Fe3O2 as the precursor via solid-reaction method exhibits high surface, uniform fine and loose particles. Although prepared by simple milling method, rather than co-precipitation and melting methods, SR catalyst achieves unexpected performance for FTO. FTO reaction were carried out at 320 °C, 10 bar, H2/CO ratio of 1.6 and GHSV of 11,400 h ̶ 1. The conversion of CO and selectivity as well as the yield during FTO over SR, CP and FM are listed in Table S3. Under the conditions similar with industrial operation, all the catalysts display high CO conversion levels (ranging from 92 to 96%). In addition, the catalytic performance is usually compared with Fe-time-yield (FTY), which was defined as the number of CO moles converted to hydrocarbons over per gram of iron per second [31]. The FTY value of SR catalyst is 5.62 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1 which is almost two times higher than that of CP (3.19 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1) or 3 times higher than that of FM (1.98 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1). Clearly, more active sites are exposed on the surface of SR catalyst. In addition to FTY of catalyst, the selectivity of product is a very important indicator for the performance of catalyst. The selectivity to C2 to C4 olefins of FM catalyst is only 25%, and while the selectivity to C5+ is as high as 41%. For CP catalyst, the selectivity to light olefins of 33% and selectivity to C5+ of 29% are achieved. The highest selectivity to light olefins around 40% and lowest selectivity to C5+ product less than 11% are obtained over SR catalyst. At the same time, the selectivity to methane for SR catalyst is 30%, which is also slightly higher than FM (˜21%) and CP (˜23%). We suggest that the surface of SR catalyst prepared by solid-reaction method promotes H2 adsorption, leading to the formation of less C5+ fragments. Fig. 4 a demonstrates the FTY of all the catalysts as a function of time on stream during the FTO reaction. No clear deactivation is observed for these catalysts within the time on steam of 100 h. All the catalysts achieve satisfactory stability under conditions studied. Stable selectivity to the target products, light olefins is also obtained similar with the FTY trend. It is worth noting that compared with FM and CP catalysts, SR catalyst exhibits higher activity and selectivity to light olefins during the whole time on stream. But the activity of SR catalyst before 12 h declined with time. The fluctuation for the activity and selectivity of SR catalyst is attributed to the oxidation of Fe5C2 to Fe3O4 species by H2O [32] or the covering of carbon layer on some active sites [33], reducing the number of active species at the initial stage. However, following reaction, carbon deposition can also be transformed to Fe5C2, which is responsible for the gradually increase in FTY. As both FTY and selectivity fluctuate with TOS, repeated experiments have been performed. The typical results are demonstrated in Fig. S2. Clearly, the results can be reproduced satisfactorily. Al, K, Ca and Mg are usually included in the catalysts. Sm is the new promoter in the present work. The catalysts with samarium promoter prepared via solid-state reaction method improves the activity of catalyst, with the decrease in selectivity to CO2 (Table S4 and S5). The phenomenon may be attributed to that K promoter can easily migrate to the catalyst surface without samarium promoter during FTO process, resulting in the high basicity on the catalyst surface. Stronger basicity promotes the dissociation and adsorption of CO, and inhibits the dissociation adsorption of H2. Thus, deposited carbon from CO dissociation can not completely react with dissociated H, resulting in carbon deposition which covers the active center of the catalyst and decreases the activity of the catalyst. The presence of Sm promoter (in the form of Sm2O3 following activation) significantly improves the activity and selectivity. As Sm2O3 has very high melting point (2262 °C) indicating the low mobility in the catalyst. In addition, the radius of Sm3+ is much larger than that of Fe ions. Therefore, different from other promoters, it is difficult for Sm to form solid-solution like structure with Fe. As a result, Sm2O3 tends to locate at the surface or boundary of the catalyst crystalline. Following the segregation of K, it may interact with Sm2O3 which may reduce the basicity of the catalyst surface. Thus, the activity of catalyst is improved and samarium promoter also decreases the selectivity to CO2 via inhibiting the Boudouard reactions of CO. Similar results have been obtained for FM catalysts. As indicated in Fig. 4, both the activity and selectivity to light olefins over SR, CP and FM catalysts differ significantly. Hence, a series of characterizations were adopted to explain this phenomenon. 3.4 Reduction behavior and phases structure evolution The reducibility of the fresh catalysts was investigated by TPR technique in H2 and CO atmosphere respectively. The H2-TPR profiles are illustrated in Fig. 5 a. Catalysts derived from different preparation methods exhibit different reduction behaviors. The catalysts prepared via co-precipitation (CP) and solid-state reaction (SR) methods display three reduction peaks. The peaks at 375 °C and 405 °C for SR and CP catalysts are attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 which is consistent with the literature [34]. The peaks at 528 °C and 574 °C are assigned to the reduction of Fe3O4 to α-Fe [34]. The reduction peaks which appear at 768 °C for CP and 706 °C for SR are the reduction of Fe3O4 particles covered by K. K inhibits the reduction of iron oxide in H2 atmosphere [35]. However, FM catalyst only shows a wide reduction peak at the range of 450–720 °C, which may be caused by the overlapping of reduction peaks of Fe3O4 and FeO to α-Fe. Because FM catalyst is mainly composed by Fe3O4 and FeO structures, which is consistent with XRD (Fig. 3). In addition, the other peaks (734 and 764 °C) are attributed to the reduction of Fe3O4 particles covered by K and the refractory complex formed through iron and promoters, respectively. Among all the catalysts, SR catalyst possesses the lowest reduction temperatures. Thus, SR is facilely reduced in H2 atmosphere compared with CP and FM. We suggest that the small crystalline size of iron particles in SR facilitates the reduction. Tao [36] also reported that the large crystallite size of α-Fe2O3 formed from high calcination temperature is not favorable for the reduction in H2 and syngas. Fe2O3 is reduced and carburized in CO atmosphere at elevated temperatures [37]. With CO-TPR technique, it was suggested that the peak temperature at above 575 °C is attributed to the deposition of amorphous carbon derived from the carburizing and Boudouard reactions of CO (3 and 4) [7,11,12]. (1) Fe2O3 + CO → Fe3O4 + CO2 (2) Fe3O4 + CO → FeCx + CO2 (3) CO+CO ↔ CO2 + C (4) Fe3O4 + C → FeCx + CO2 Fig. 5b discloses the CO-TPR-MS profiles of the catalysts. Unlike the profiles of H2-TPR, CO-TPR profiles present a low temperature peak at around 300 °C corresponding to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 over CP and SR catalysts. These temperatures are significantly lower than the reduction by H2 indicating that CO facilitates the reduction of Fe2O3. The peaks at the temperature range of 380–750 °C are ascribed to the reduction and carburization of Fe3O4. For SR catalyst, there are two peaks of the reduction and carburization of Fe3O4, which suggested that Fe3O4 combined with CO forming FeCx (2), and Fe3O4 also combines with C derived from CO + CO ↔ CO2 + C (3) forming FeCx (4). However, CP and FM exhibit only one carburization peak. In addition, the peak area of CO-TPR does not represent the content of iron carbide, due to the existence of Boudouard reactions of CO. To obtain the phase structure of catalysts after the reduction at 400–500°C under H2 flow for 13 h, the iron catalysts were examined by XRD (Fig. 6 a). As indicated in Fig. 6, reduced catalysts (FM and CP) disclose a well-crystallized α-Fe (JCPDS 06 ̶ 0696) phase with characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 44.7°, 65.0°, 82.3° and 98.9°, corresponding to the facets of (110), (200), (211) and (220), respectively. Fe peaks were relatively narrow and well-defined indicating a well-crystallized structure with relatively high purity. However, as indicated in Fig. 6b, (110) peak shows that the peak shifts to low 2θ indicating the formation of γ-Fe over SR catalyst [38]. Meanwhile, the presence of quartz beads in the catalysts of SR was resulted from the diluter in the catalytic bed. In addition, for the fused catalyst (FM), the diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 at 2θ of 30.1°, 35.7° and 62.5° were detected, indicating that FM was not reduced completely, which is consistent with H2-TPR. By contrast, CP and SR catalysts were reduced completely under a high GHSV [30,39]. Thus, the reduction temperature of 400–500 °C is sufficient for the complete reduction of SR and CP catalysts. XRD patterns of the catalysts after 100 h of time on steam during FTO are presented in Fig. 7 . It is observed that Hägg carbide (Fe5C2) was the main phase for all the catalysts, corresponding to the PDF card (JCPDC 51-0997). The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 30.1°, 35.4°, 56.9°, 62.5°in spent catalysts are assigned to Fe3O4 (JCPDC 19-0629). However, there is only one weak peak of Fe3O4 in terms of SR catalyst. By contrast, CP and FM catalysts display more and stronger diffraction peaks of Fe3O4. The crystal sizes of χ-Fe5C2 are listed in Table S6. No significant difference is observed between these catalysts. The peak at 26.4° is attributed to the (002) facet of carbon (JCPDC 41–1487), produced from Boudouard reaction of CO, consisted with CO-TPR experiments. It is well accepted that Fe5C2 is one of key active phases, rather than Fe3O4 in FTO process. Hence, SR catalyst derived from solid-state reaction provides more active sites, which leads to high catalytic activity in FTO process. 3.5 Surface properties To investigate the effect of the preparation methods on the surface basicity, CO2-TPD experiments were investigated and the results are presented in Fig. 8 . CO2 desorption peaks at temperatures of 100 ̶ 150 °C, 320 ̶ 410 °C, 430 ̶ 600 °C and 600 ̶ 820 °C are observed, assigned to the weak basic sites, medium sites, strong sites and the decomposition of carbonate, respectively [40]. The profile of SR catalyst clearly indicates that there are five CO2 desorption peaks. Especially, the peak corresponding to medium basic sites is located at 376 °C which is much lower than that of CP (388 °C). Strong basic sites of all catalysts are separated into two kind of basic sites with the desorption temperatures of 430–600 °C. Clearly, there are two kinds of active sites for the adsorption of CO2. It is observed that the temperature of the strong basic sites in SR catalyst shifts lower temperature (525 °C) compared with CP (553 °C) and FM (563 °C). Generally, the CO2 adsorption sites are provided by promoters such as K, Ca, Mg, and so on. Therefore, compared with FM and CP, K, Ca and Mg disperse better over SR catalyst. Especially, K promoter plays an important role in improving the catalyst surface basicity. Yang [35] suggested that the selectivity toward methane and light hydrocarbons is inhibited by the increase in potassium content. Wan [41] confirmed that the catalyst with lower surface basicity enhances the selectivity to light hydrocarbons and methane, but decreases the selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons. Clearly, compared with CP and FM, SR catalyst exhibits relatively low surface basicity. It indicates that the SR catalyst prepared by solid reaction method possesses appropriate basicity strength, which is favorable for the improvement of the activity and the selectivity to light olefins during FTO. In order to verify the effect of K promoter on the iron based catalyst prepared by solid state reaction, we prepared a series of Fe-based catalysts with different contents of K promoters (Table S7 and S8). With the increase in K content, the selectivity to low olefins increases firstly before it drops with further addition of K. C5+ and O/P (the molar ratio of olefin to paraffin in the C2–C4 range hydrocarbons) also increase and the selectivity of methane gradually decreases with K amount. Thus, these phenomena suggest appropriate content of K promoter is favorable to the production of light olefins. XPS technique was employed to identify the surface chemistry of spent catalysts after FTO reactions. The whole XPS spectra (Fig. 9 a) suggest that catalyst surface is composed by Fe, C, O and K. Their surface compositions are listed in Table 2 . For SR catalyst, almost no surface K is observed by XPS. In deeded, K tends to migrate to the surface during reaction. Consequently, high K surface content is expected after reaction. However, as listed in Table 2, following FTO reaction, the surfaces of the catalysts are heavily covered by large amounts of carbon (80%–90%). The XRD result of SR catalyst after FTO shows a strong peak of carbon, which is consistent with XPS. It is well accepted that K promoter promotes CO adsorption and dissociation, enhancing the activity of catalysts and water-gas shift reaction. In addition, K also promotes the C ̶ C coupling and increases the selectivity to hydrocarbon [42–44]. Therefore, the distribution of active metals and promoters affect the activity and selectivity of FTO products. However, significant amounts of K promoters are concentrated on catalyst surface for CP and FM. It is worth noting that the carbon content of SR catalyst is 89.39%. The surface carbon compositions for CP and FM are 85.03% and 79.19%, respectively. This result is consistent with the selectivity to CO2 (Table S3). Generally, there are two pathways to generate CO2. CO2 can be formed via water-gas-shift reaction (WGS), or via Boudouard reaction of CO reaction [45]. As demonstrated in Fig. 9b, Fe 2p XPS spectrum exhibits two strong peaks at 710.9 eV and 724.3 eV, which are assigned to Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 for Fe3O4 [32,46]. The weak peaks at 706.9 eV and 719.2 eV are attributed to Fe5C2 species [47], implying the coexistence of Fe3O4 and Fe5C2 on the catalyst surface. These results are consistent with that of XRD (Fig. 7). The ratios of Fe5C2 to Fe3O4 are listed in Table 3 . Clearly, the ratio of Fe5C2 to Fe3O4 in SR catalyst is 0.16, which is significantly higher than that of CP (0.14) and FM (0.08). Actually, the ratio agrees well with the conversion of CO and selectivity to light olefins as shown in Fig. 4. It is reasonable to suggest that there are more active phases existed on SR catalyst. It also explains the reason that SR catalyst achieves high activity. Fig. 10 displays the TEM images and particle size distribution of the spent catalysts after FTO reactions. With TEM images, significant amounts of carbon deposition are observed. Following FTO reactions, catalysts remains the form of nanoparticles. The average size of spent CP catalyst is determined to be 24.5 nm, and 30.6 nm for FM catalyst. By contrast, SR catalyst presents uniformly dispersed particles with the average size of 23.3 nm, which is significantly smaller than FM and CP. Due to the formation of core-shell structure (carbon deposition over catalyst surface), the aggregation of nanoparticles is inhibited significantly. Clearly, preparation method affects the precursor structure of catalysts, which further results in the difference in reducibility and carburization behavior. Especially, following solid-state reaction, γ-Fe2O3 precursor was obtained for SR catalyst via the decomposition of iron oxalate. It affords the formation of fine particles and uniform and narrow particle size distribution. These conclusions are well consistent with the literature [15,48]. In addition, Fischer-Tropsch reaction is also suggested to be structure sensitive reaction [49], which means that the particle size and structure of iron carbide or metal influence the activity of catalyst. Therefore, the particles were further investigated by HR-TEM and the results are shown in Fig. 11 . As displayed in Fig. 11, clear core-shell structures are identified. Following reaction, iron particles are encapsulated by carbon deposition. This structure contributes the stability of catalysts significantly. In addition, spent catalysts after Fischer-Tropsch reaction show various crystalline facets of Fe5C2 species. The lattice distance of 0.205 nm assigned to (510) facet of Hägg carbide for FM catalyst is detected [32,50]. In addition, (220) and (111) facets of Fe3O4 are also observed with lattice space of 0.296 nm and 0.485 nm, respectively. This is consistent with the XRD results demonstrated in Fig.7 where Fe3O4 was also detected over FM. It is suggested that Fe5C2 (510) crystal facet enhances carbon coupling and suppresses methane formation, leading to high activity in FTO [16]. The traditional catalyst in FTS process mainly consists of iron carbide (ε-Fe2C, χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C, and Fe7C3) and Fe3O4. It is widely accepted that iron carbide is the active phase of FTS, while Fe3O4 is the active phase of water-gas-shift reaction (WGS). Usually, iron carbide is unstable under the reaction conditions and tends to be oxidized to Fe3O4 by H2O and CO2 in the reaction system [32]. In addition, iron carbide also includes many crystal planes. For example, (510) and (021) faces of Fe5C2 with high Miller index and (001) (010) (111) of Fe5C2 with low Miller index [51]. It is reported that the surface energy of different crystal facets affects the exposure degree of facets. The (021) and (510) facets of Fe5C2 can be exposed to the catalyst surface with high area because of lower surface energy compared with other facets. However, the crystal facet of Fe5C2 exposed to catalyst surface is related to the CO activation, including the direct and H-assisted CO dissociation pathways [51]. It is reported that CO direct dissociation pathway possess higher catalytic activity than hydrogen assisted dissociation, because CO direct dissociation requires lower energy barrier in the whole process compared with hydrogen assisted dissociation. The (021) and (510) facets of Fe5C2 facilitates the direct dissociation pathway of CO [52]. However, SR catalyst with Fe5C2 (021) crystal plane leads to higher catalytic activity, which is consistent with activity data (Fig. 4a). In addition, it has been reported that the crystal planes of Fe5C2 also influence the distribution of products, such as the selectivity to CH4. As listed in Table S3, the selectivity of FM catalyst agrees well with this conclusion. Compared with CP and SR catalysts, lowest CH4 selectivity and highest selectivity to C5+ hydrocarbons are obtained over FM catalyst. By contrast, facet of (021) of Fe5C2 with lattice distance of 0.208 nm over SR catalyst was determined, which is consistent with the XRD analysis [33]. For CP catalyst, (112) facets of Fe5C2 with lattice distance of 0.211 nm was achieved. During FTO reactions, CO activation includes the direct and H-assisted CO dissociation pathways [51,53]. Facets of Fe5C2 play a major role in the dissociation of CO [52]. As the first step during FTO, it affects the activity and selectivity of products. It was reported that the effective barrier for the formation of CH4 (Eeff,CH4) is one of the key factors to control the selectivity to CH4 [54,55]. The lower the Eeff,CH4, the easier it is to generate CH4. It was found that the effective barrier (Eeff,CH4) of Fe5C2 (510) is 2.39 eV which is higher than that of (100) facet (1.89 eV), suggesting that the step-like Fe5C2 (100) facets have more methane active sites than the terrace-like (510), which is consistent with the experimental results [49]. Zhao [42] suggested that the effect of (111), (100) and (110) crystal of Fe5C2 catalyst modified by K promoter on surface carbon hydrogenation. The result shows that (111) facet can be most easily hydrogenated, while the (110) facet has the highest barrier and is hardly hydrogenated. However, (021) facet of Fe5C2 is exposed to the SR catalyst surface with high area. It was suggested that high Miller index surface (021) facilitates the exposure and the dissociation of CO. (021) facet affords the direct dissociation of CO [52]. It is one of most active structure for the hydrogenation of CO. Clearly, exposed (021) facet may contribute the high activity and high selectivity to light olefins for SR catalyst. These results indicate that the crystal plane of iron carbide can largely adjust the activity and product selectivity of the catalyst, which is also a problem to be solved by researchers in the future. 4 Conclusions In this work, SR catalyst prepared via simple solid-state reaction method, with high surface area and small uniform particle size, exhibits higher FTO activity (5.62 × 10−3 molCO gFe -1 s-1) and selectivity to light olefins (40%) than traditional precipitated and fused iron catalysts (CP and FM). High activity is attributed to high surface area, small iron particles, high reducibility and formation of Fe5C2 active phases. In addition, the high selectivity to light olefins is mainly attributed to proper surface basicity and the exposure of iron carbide facets, such as (021) facet, on the catalyst surface. This approach provides potential route to enhance the selectivity tolower olefins and FTO activity. coredata.dc:description: Iron catalyst was fabricated via simple solid-state reaction of metal nitrates mixture (Fe, K, Al, Ca, Mg, Sm) with oxalic acid dihydrate at room temperature. Iron catalysts prepared by conventional methods, such as co-precipitation and fusing, are also included as comparison. The performances of catalysts were evaluated by the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) in a fixed bed reactor. The results indicate that uniform nanoparticles were obtained with surface area as high as 38.7 m2/g prepared by solid-state reaction. Following calcination at 500 °C, γ-Fe2O3 were obtained as the catalyst precursor. By contrast, α-Fe2O3 was the main precursor derived from co-precipitation. In addition, γ-Fe2O3 prepared by solid-state reaction facilitates the formation of active phase, Fe5C2 with the exposure of (021) facet. High Miller index surface (021) facilitates the adsorption and the dissociation of CO, which contributes the high activity and high selectivity to light olefins. Consequently, compared with conventional catalysts, solid-state reaction derived catalysts exhibit much higher FTO reaction activity and selectivity to lower olefins. The FTY value of 5.62 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1 was obtained which is almost two times higher than that of catalyst prepared by co-precipitation (3.19 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1) or 3 times higher than that of catalyst prepared by fusing method (1.98 × 10 ̶ 3 molCO gFe ̶ 1 s ̶ 1). The selectivity to light olefins of around 40% is obtained which is significantly higher than that of the reference catalysts (25% and 33% respectively). The present study provides a promising pathway to prepare iron based catalysts at room temperature.
coredata.dc:title: γ-Fe2O3 as the precursor of iron based catalyst prepared by solid-state reaction at room temperature for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins
